newsitem.title: UK: GEC bows to shareholder pressure on boardroom pay.
newsitem.headline: GEC bows to shareholder pressure on boardroom pay.

text.p: British defence and engineering giant General Electric Company has bowed to shareholder anger over a controversial pay package for its new managing director George Simpson by toughening the contract's performance targets.

The company said on Monday evening it had amended the contract, under which Simpson will now receive a huge block of share options if GEC's share price exceeds by at least 10 percent the growth in the FTSE 100 index over a three year period, instead of the six months as had previously been agreed.
"GEC and Mr Simpson have always envisaged that challenging performance criteria would be attached to awards made to Mr Simpson," the group said in a brief faxed statement.

Senior company executives met the Association of British Insurers' (ABI) earlier on Monday to try to head off a possible revolt at its annual meeting in four days time, amid rising institutional anger that GEC was being too generous to Simpson.
GEC added that Simpson had agreed to the amendment and the criteria complied with ABI guidelines. The terms previously agreed reflected Simpson's arrangements with his employer then.
The Times newspaper said Simpson himself had been prompting the addition of stricter performance targets to his contract.
It was unclear on Monday evening how shareholders would vote at the annual meeting. A source at one financial institution said it would make its decision "soon," but did not elaborate.
Simpson's three year contract gives him annual pay of up to 1.5 million pounds ($2.35 million), including pension contributions, plus a complicated package of share options.
The former chief executive of Lucas Industries, who takes over at GEC from Lord Weinstock, has already been dubbed "the fattest cat of all" by British newspapers.
His controversial deal has turned up the heat in the debate about top executives' pay sparked last year when former British Gas chief executive Cedric Brown was awarded a 75 percent rise.

Mounting public anger over "fat cat" salaries prompted the government to set up a committee to curb boardroom excesses. But despite guidelines set by the committee, led by Marks & Spencer chairman Sir Richard Greenbury, executive salaries are rising. ($1=.6396 Pound)
